bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mary A. Benjamin, August 13, 1946

div1.p: Hench informs Benjamin that he is keeping two Madam Curie letters which he purchased from Benjamin seven years earlier. He is returning the rest of the letters and she can do with them as she wishes.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Mary A. Benjamin, August 13, 1946
div1.opener:
August 13, 1946
Miss Mary A. Benjamin
c/o Walter R. Benjamin
655 Fifth Avenue
New York, New York
My dear Miss Benjamin:
div1.p:
Through the years I have had considerable satisfaction
from practically everything I ever bought from you. However,
in 1939 I slipped. I bought from you the collection of letters of
“famous scientists, chemists, writers, et cetera” written in connection
with Madam Curie's visit to America. Regarding this collection, see
the enclosed letter. (Will you kindly return the letter to me?)
Although I had some doubts in my mind at the time, I bought the letters
almost exclusively in order to get the one or two Curie items which
were therein. Each time I looked over my collection, I found this bunch
of letters which have never interested me in the slightest and which,
as the years passed, I found more annoying. They may be of some value
to somebody, but they are of no interest to me. I have been tempted
to throw them away, but realized that what may not interest me may be
of interest to someone else. I am therefore returning them all to you
and you can do any one of the following things with them. 1. Throw
them away if they are of no value to anyone. 2. Give them to someone
with my compliments if you know anyone who really wants them. 3. Accept
them and sell them for what they are worth and either (a) keep the
entire proceeds for yourself with my compliments or (b) apply on my
account whatever token payment or value those letters might have if
you were to buy them from a stranger now. If, without the Curie items,
these letters are really worth anything and you want them, I am glad
to let you have them and I have every confidence in the way you will
handle the matter.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
